awd_abstract_narration:
PI Last Name: Eckel
Title: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Escaping Secular Stagnation with Unconventional Policy
Proposal ID:  1851920 
Institution: Texas A&M University

Abstract

This research project uses laboratory experiments to understand periods of prolonged low economic growth, as distinct from cyclical low-growth periods.  The goal of the project is to simulate an economy in the laboratory within which we can trigger a permanent decline in economic activity along with falling prices, and then to explore various policy interventions that have the potential to repair the stagnant economy. In particular, the project focuses on what actions policy makers can take (monetary and fiscal policy) to restore the experimental economy to full employment.  The research explores whether the timing and contextual communication of policy can influence the efficacy of policy. 
 
The laboratory experiments in this project are designed to explore secular stagnation in a closed economy. Specifically, the research implements a recent formalization of secular stagnation that uses an overlapping-generations structure to break the representative agent assumption and allow for endogenous bouts of activity at the zero lower bound (ZLB).  Exogenous deleveraging shocks can trigger spending gluts that create deflation, and lead to a secular stagnation equilibrium, which can be unique. The objective of the research is to identify whether deflationary and inflationary equilibria emerge when they are unique, and to explore equilibrium selection when multiple equilibria exist. Additionally, the project investigates the ability of monetary policy, in the form of inflation targeting, and fiscal policy, consisting of "helicopter drops" financed using lump-sum taxes levied on the middle-aged cohort in our experimental economy, to pull the economy out of a deflationary equilibrium following a debt-deleveraging shock. Both potential remedies improve economic conditions through an expectations channel by making households more optimistic about future economic conditions. Finally, the project studies the effect of variation in both the timing and contextual communication of policy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Economists have grown increasingly concerned over the decade that some industrialized economies are now contending with long-term recessionary pressures. The primary impetus of this concern is a decades-long downward trend in both long- and short-term interest rates that culminated in many major central banks leaving interest rates at or near zero for about a decade following the financial collapse of 2008. The concern is that whatever has driven rates consistently toward zero will make low-or-zero interest rates a much more frequent issue in the future. If so, central banks will become increasingly constrained in their ability to use conventional monetary policy (changing nominal interest rates) to rescue ailing economies. 

Our primary goal in this project was to explore other tools central bankers might use to stave off these long-term recessionary pressures and restore economic health. Because data are so limited, we turned to laboratory experimental methods to gain insight into these questions. To this end, we designed a flexible experimental framework to serve as a wind tunnel for testing policy alternatives in a safe, tightly-controlled, replicable, and cost-effective manner. In this framework, experimental economies evolve according to the price expectations and spending decisions of participants. We consistently are able to generate long-term recessions in the experimental economies and then allow a central bank to implement different policies to overcome the recessions. Importantly, this data-rich framework provides insight into which policies work, which fail, and why. 

We used this framework to test two widely-debated approaches to policy. First, we allowed the central bank to use negative interest rates to increase spending, promote growth, and generate employment. Second, we allowed the central bank to permanently increase its inflation target. 

Allowing a central bank to permanently increase its inflation target - the policy recommended by related economic theory - works by increasing the public's inflation expectations. If the public expects higher prices tomorrow, then they will spend more today to avoid those higher prices. This increased spending today puts upward pressure on prices, which leads to inflation, more production, and more employment. Crucially, economic theory says only that this policy could work but cannot say if it will work. We show the policy fails to save experimental economies from long-term recessions because participants in our experiment do not find the new, higher inflation target credible. 

On the other hand, allowing central banks to use negative interest rates is very effective in our experimental economies. Negative interest rates cause savings accounts to shrink over time. Participants in our experiment are better off increasing their spending and saving less whenever interest rates become negative. This increased spending puts upward pressure on prices, output, and employment. As prices rise, so do expectations about future prices. 

Our results suggest that central bankers might be able to safely and effectively employ negative interest rates should the need arise. However, relying on policies that work by changing expectations may not be effective. This is because the conditions that pushed a central bank to the bounds of conventional policy may undermine the credibility necessary for such interventions to work.
